Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, swirling my fork in my mashed potatoes as my family chatted about what to do this weekend. My brother suggested a movie, my mom wanted a picnic, and my dad was all for a hike. I smiled, trying to join in, but my mind kept drifting back to the volunteer work I’d done that afternoon. Someone I’d helped had mentioned a local event, and my family’s conversation was veering dangerously close to that topic. My sister asked if I’d heard anything interesting lately, and everyone looked at me, expecting me to share. As a sister, I wanted to be part of the laughter and stories, to contribute and connect. But as a volunteer, I knew I had to respect the privacy of those I’d helped, even if nothing sensitive had been said. The pressure built inside me—my family’s eager faces on one side, my sense of responsibility on the other. I felt my heart race, caught between wanting to belong and needing to protect someone else’s trust.
